content.title: Vascular Hemodynamics
content.definition: The physics of blood flow through the cardiovascular system, governed by principles of fluid dynamics. Understanding hemodynamics is essential for interpreting vascular pathology, planning interventions, and predicting outcomes.

ohms_law_analog.clinical_application: Blood flow is driven by pressure differences and opposed by resistance

poiseuille_law.key_insight: Radius is raised to 4th power - small changes in diameter have profound effects on resistance

continuity_equation.application: Velocity increases as cross-sectional area decreases (stenosis)

bernoulli_principle.application: Pressure drops as velocity increases across stenosis

critical_stenosis.definition: Stenosis causing hemodynamically significant flow reduction
critical_stenosis.rest_vs_exercise: May only be significant during increased demand

collateral_circulation.flow_redistribution: Maintains tissue perfusion despite main vessel disease

turbulence.turbulent_consequences: Energy loss, vessel wall injury, bruits

venous_hemodynamics.capacitance: 70% of blood volume in venous system

valves.function: Prevent retrograde flow, direct blood centrally

hydrostatic_pressure.walking: Drops to 20-30 mmHg with calf pump activation

ankle_brachial_index.principle: Ratio of ankle to brachial systolic pressure

doppler_velocity.psv_ratio: Peak systolic velocity ratio across stenosis
doppler_velocity.threshold: PSV >200 cm/s or ratio >2 suggests >50% stenosis

waveform_analysis.biphasic: Moderate disease - loss of reverse component

learning_objectives: Apply Poiseuille's law to understand stenosis significance
Interpret Doppler velocity changes across stenoses
Understand venous hemodynamics and valve function
clinical_pearls: Radius to the 4th power - 50% diameter stenosis = 94% area reduction
50% diameter stenosis is often 'critical' at rest
Triphasic → Biphasic → Monophasic indicates progressive disease
Velocity doubles if area halves (continuity equation)
Venous pressure at ankle drops from 100 to 30 mmHg when walking - calf pump effect
common_misconceptions: Misconception: 50% stenosis means 50% flow reduction - Reality: Flow reduction depends on whether stenosis is 'critical' based on vessel, collaterals, and demand
